utterances: Do you think so?
I know so.
Oh, my god.
Like wildlife, so it's your craft and the audience.
And hopefully you'll make a great living at it and you know, when people start out in the business, and she's done it for four years, but they say, you know.
When I started it was like 20 people, like Crystal and me and Leno and Kaufman, and you know, there were more, but we had some good spots, and there were only a handful of clubs.
But the point is, you know, we never dreamed we would make a living at it.
We were just - it was like being in Paris back in 18th century, you know, being in these cafes with other artists.
We just said, this is the only thing we can do, we're idiots.

You know, at least I said that, and I tell people, whatever art you're in, you know, ballerina, comedian, writer, if you're going into this thing other than for the passion, you know, check out now cause that ain't worth that, man.
I mean, she knows that.

I mean, you got to really want this more than anything because it's really tough and ruthless and a small percentage pay the bills doing it, so you know, you can really hang in there and not look back, that's the way to go.
But I forgot my preamble.
And what's that?
Go ahead.
Very fast, and then I'll answer everything because you had 19 producers call me for the last hour.

Number one, Larry David just finished a Woody Allen movie and people ask me this, so he says he'll probably come back for a seventh season of ""Curb,"" which I'm thrilled to be part of because I think it's comically authentic and wonderful.
Number two, I got married for the first time, late in life, which I think is - I had to because I'm a recovering drug addict and alcoholic for 14 years.

And the reason my book is out now with new work is because my demographics is like teenagers to people in their 60s and their 70s, so if I can save one life by putting it back on audio and doing some new work, that's why the book and the audio is out.
And that's it.
I'm on the road constantly, and I'm off to God knows where, Pittsburg and Atlantic City and Minneapolis, and who cares?
Now let's talk about the road.
Well...
(Soundbite of laughter)
I'm hoping to see you out here on the road.
It's a little hard but it's wonderful.
I'm in Milwaukee this week.
I'm in Seattle in a couple of weeks.
I travel all over.
It's a beautiful country.
You're always pitching those plugs, you got to do that.
Now I'm all yours and thank you, and George Carlin, he's laughing at me now in heaven, saying, how come he didn't curse and got thrown off the air?
One of the great comedians.
You know, I should say this to my fellow comedian.
You know, George Carlin and I worked very differently.
I can say that at 60 - I'll be 61 this weekend - I have about 2,000 pages in the last four years on my computer, which has about 20, 30 hours of new material.

I scroll it in the cities, I try to do about a half hour of new material each set, and then ad-lib the rest, and then if I'm doing stuff that's cooking the last month, I'll do that but if the audience is good, I'll take it to another place.
George, who had a record number of specials - it doesn't mean my way is right but I couldn't do it his way.
I would call him and say, how's the special coming?
And he'd say, I have a minute and two seconds left to write.
And you know, he did it like a play, which is, you know, there's something to say about that, too, but I couldn't go on stage knowing what I was going to say.
It's a different way to work.
It's sort of scary, but you know, if you don't have fun on stage, what's the point of going on?
So there are different ways of working.
I just miss George a lot.

He had a crazy life, as well, with drugs, with rock n' roll and all of that sort of stuff, and he was sober three years when he died, which I think bears noting because, you know - and I don't preach about it.
I did it for me, he did it for himself.
But you know, if a guy like George Carlin can get sober, and there's million of George Carlin fans and you're having problems with drugs and alcohol, if George can get sober, anybody can.
All right, I'll shut up.
How are you?
(Soundbite of laughter)
Good.
Let's see if we can get some listeners involved in the conversation, too.
I was listening to her, I thought she was done.
No, no. We....
No one tells me anything.
I thought I was talking about teenage pregnancy.
No, that's later in the show, and you know, we're just going to leave that alone.
Let's see if we can get callers on the line.
800-989-8255, and Jack is with us from Monmouth in Illinois.
Hi, how you going?
All right.
Congratulations to both of your guests for other - just what we recently talked about.
Now I've been doing amateur stuff for about six years, and I wanted to see if both of you could speak a little more about the unscrupulous takes that amateurs...
What do you mean by that?
Well, I mean, I just do open mics and I've won a couple of contests but I've never never got a booking, partly because I don't live anywhere near a good network.

But anyway, there is this amazing bitterness between, especially upstarts like me, that maybe I'm guilty of it, too, but there's just like this weird tension between comics that is found nowhere else.
Esther Ku, is there tension and bitterness among comics?
You want to go first, sweetheart?
And sweetheart's not sexist, by the way.
I apologize.
Ms.
KU.
OK.
Is there bitterness?
Yeah, I think so.
And how does it manifest itself?
People probably talk behind your back.
I mean, when people see me, though, they're nice to my face but then I hear something nasty that they said behind my back, you know.
It's like high school.
Comedy is like such a small world, you know.
You see the same people everywhere, and people gossip.
That's true.
That's all true.

It was different when I started because there were fewer comedians and people would actually hang out and help each other with their sets and get them ready for the ""Tonight Show,"" and it was more of a sister and brotherhood.
The deal is this.
I started with a negative tone.

There are some wonderful agents and mangers and people who are not just getting their 10 percent or if they know their clients are sick and need help they'll just send them out and then they'll hear the news that they died.
The bottom line is this.
There's so many comedians that if you can't - everyone can have their authentic self if they just talk about their own lives.
It's a real easy way to take other people's material when the guy leaves town or just steal.
Period.
I mean, big stars steal.
You know, comedians without talent steal.
And you know, if they want to live their life that way, that's fine.
But the bottom line is that, you know, that side of the coin, to me, the artistic side really stinks.
But in terms of the business end, it's just like acting.
They want the best actors, unless you're a huge superstar, the best actors for the cheapest amount of money.
That's what their goal is.
The same thing with people who buy comedians.
They want the best act for the least amount of money and they'll do anything they can to put you in the worst hotel room, give you the worst accommodations, flying, you name it.
So you know, when you get some clout, you have to make sure you really look out for yourself because really, only - no one else will but you and hopefully some proper representatives.
Jack, good luck to you.
Good luck to you both.
Thank you.
Thanks very much for your call, Jack.
And we're going to ask Esther Ku and Richard Lewis to stay with us.
If you'd like to join us to talk about the business of stand-up comedy, give us a call, 800-989-8255.
Email, talk@npr.org.
I'm Neal Conan.
It's the Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
This is Talk of the Nation.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
Neil Strauss, a cultural reporter for the New York Times, once wrote of stand-up comedy, there's only one thing more humiliating than being a stand-up comic and that's trying to be a stand-up comic.
That's the lesson I learned after six months trying to make it as a comedian.
The bottom rung of the comedy ladder can be uglier, crueler and more demeaning that in any other line of entertainment.
(Soundbite of laughter)
That's it.
I could speak in 16 cities now, but I'm not.
I wanted to look stupid.
In his book ""The Other Great Depression,"" comedian Richard Lewis wrote that it's a capricious, self-centered and cruel business.
We've got two stand-ups with us today.
Richard Lewis is among them.
Also Esther Ku, who is a rising star in New York City.
If you'd like to join the conversation about the business of stand-up comedy, give us a call, 800-989-8255.
Email us, talk@npr.org.
And this is Steve, Steve with us on the line from St. Louis in Missouri.
Yeah.
Hi.

I wanted to know if when you were first starting out and kind of progressively as you got into the business, did you retain a lawyer or an agent or somebody like that to kind of manage corporation for you?
You know, overlook contracts and that type of thing, or did you go on your own?
And if you eventually retained that type of person but you didn't earlier, what was the difference that you noticed in terms of how you were able to shop around and get your name out and so forth?
Well, Esther Ku?
It's easy for me.
My high school buddy was graduated number one in Harvard, came out here and became a superstar lawyer when he was like in his 20s, and he took care of me for free until I could pay him.
And the bottom line is this, is you have to have an attorney, even early on because they have to look over - because agents and managers come and go.
I've had like a thousand.
I'm down to like a dairy farmer in Iowa if I fire this next crew.
So you know, my attorney looks at everything and then I'll get a fax with all these red lines and I'm like, what, are you kidding me?
Are you nuts?
